Award.AwardTitle: IONiC: Transforming Education Through Collaborative Development of Materials at the Frontiers of Inorganic Chemistry

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of this project is to improve student learning in inorganic chemistry on a national scale through design, implementation, evaluation and dissemination of classroom and laboratory activities that incorporate topics in cutting-edge research. Four professional development workshops deepen faculty content knowledge in emerging research topics in materials, bioinorganic chemistry, catalysis, and organometallic chemistry. Workshops are led by pedagogy and discipline experts from a variety of institution types, including leading researchers in these areas. Teaching materials based on the research are produced by workshop participants and reviewed by the expert workshop leaders. Workshop participants join an online community of inorganic chemists and disseminate their work on the Virtual Inorganic Pedagogical Electronic Resources (VIPEr) web site. VIPEr, a platform for collaboration, conversation, and dissemination, is home to more than 550 registered faculty users and serves as a dynamic community for the evaluation and improvement of these materials. Workshop participants and others in the VIPEr community test the learning materials and report student learning outcomes on VIPEr. Virtual versions of the four workshops are also made available on VIPEr.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF-supported Transforming Undergraduate Education in Science project grew out of the Interactive Online Network of Inorganic Chemists (IONiC), founded to advance inorganic chemistry education and led by 11 faculty at predominantly undergraduate institutions. The IONiC community maintains a curricular repository on VIPEr (the Virtual Inorganic Pedagogical Electronic Resource, www.ionicviper.org), dedicated to advancing inorganic chemistry education.


The goals of the project were to communicate the latest advances in inorganic chemistry to faculty teaching the subject by creating and using teaching materials that incorporated these advances while growing the active IONiC community. Over 100 faculty participated in one of five summer workshops dedicated to faculty development and content creation that have resulted in many new and enthusiastic IONiC community members and high quality teaching materials. The development of high quality learning objects (LOs) utilizing the recent primary literature has been a core outcome. The total number of LOs developed at these workshops is now 169. The developed materials were disseminated through the VIPEr website and have been broadly adopted by the inorganic community as determined by VIPEr user surveys.


Beyond content development, these workshops have provided professional development opportunities to promote better teaching and an increasingly engaged IONiC community. IONiC has used a multipronged approach to build connections within and beyond the chemistry community. We have used the VIPEr BITeS blog (BITeS blog), electronic newsletters, Community Challenges (Community Challenges), our Facebook group (186 members), and Twitter (@VIPEr_Flo) as ways to draw people back to the website on a regular basis and highlight particular LOs or areas where we would like people to contribute new LOs. Members of the leadership group have publicized our collaboration and the VIPEr resource through 12 publications.  We have given more than 80 seminars and presentations over the past ten years and have presented at regional, national, and international conferences on chemistry and chemical education. We have reached out beyond the chemistry community to diverse audiences including those focused on the scholarship of teaching and learning, technology, and faculty development.


We anticipate this project continuing to provide both access to education resources and a community of practice in the future.
